fields.name: UN Parallel Corpus
fields.description: Contains data drawn from the text archives of the United Nations in New York. The data have been sorted into parallel sets, such that each member of a set represents (in most cases) a careful translation of the other member(s) in the set. All parallel sets include an English version of a document, and either a French or a Spanish version (or both).

fields.comment: Details and evaluation UKWaC corpus can be read from the Paper by Ferraresi et al
fields.name: UKWaC British English Web Corpus
fields.description: All material is taken from the .uk domain. It was part-of-speech tagged and lemmatised using TreeTagger.

fields.comment: There are various tokenized and tagged versions of the corpus that were created by Thorsten Brants.
fields.name: TAZ Newspaper Corpus
fields.description: 'die tageszeitung' Consists of the newspaper TAZ from June 1990 to March 2000

fields.name: Wackypadia
fields.description: some sort of insane repository of words put together in no particular order. We, the writers, editors and Supreme Overlords hope that You will find our prose amusing, a word which here means, "Interesting for other people to look at and possibly even read" but it is not required that your endless babblings be considered funny by anyone - either objectively or subjectively - to qualify for inclusion.

fields.name: Susanne Corpus
fields.description: A syntactically annotated corpus of English. The corpus has been obtained free of charge over the web.

fields.name: Sleepy Student Parser
fields.description: 'Sleepy' is a simple unlexicalized parser for German, returning both syntactic category and grammatical function labels in the tree.

fields.comment:
Has three directories:

brown1          103 semantically tagged Brown Corpus files (all content words tagged)
brown2          83 semantically tagged Brown Corpus files (all content words tagged)
brownv          166 semantically tagged Brown Corpus files (only verbs tagged)
fields.name: SemCor 2.0
fields.description: WordNet Semantic Concordance package

fields.name: Frankfurter Rundschau Corpus
fields.description: The ECI version of the Frankfurter Rundschau corpus, tokenized and tagged by Thorsten Brant's TNT,lemmatised and tagged with Helmut Schmid's Tree Tagger,by Michael Roth (mroth@coli)

fields.name: Recognizing Textual Entailment
fields.description: Recognizing Textual Entailment

fields.comment: All annotations were produced using a discourse annotation tool that can be downloaded from Tool (http://www.isi.edu/~marcu/discourse)
fields.name: Rhetorical Structure Theory Discourse Treebank
fields.description: RST Discourse Treebank contains a selection of 385 Wall Street Journal articles from the Penn Treebank which have been annotated with discourse structure in the framework of Rhetorical Structure Theory (RST).

fields.name: QuestionBank
fields.description: A corpus of 4000 parse-annotated questions for use in the development of parser-based linguistic resources for Question Answering.

fields.name: Projekt Gutenberg Edition 9 (2005)
fields.description: a collection of German language literary texts

fields.comment:
The Prague Dependency Treebank Version 1.0 contains

* Morphologically and syntactically annotated Czech data, 1.8MW
* Czech-English parallel Corpus, aligned, 0.9MW/1MW
* Czech raw texts (newspaper and journals), over 30MW
* Czech NLP tools (morphology, tagging)
* General annotation tools (tree editors, tree viewer)
fields.name: The Prague Dependency Treebank
fields.description: The Prague Dependency Treebank 1.0

fields.name: Penn Treebank 3
fields.description: The Penn Treebank (PTB) project selected 2,499 stories from a three year Wall Street Journal (WSJ) collection of 98,732 stories for syntactic annotation.

fields.name: Penn Treebank
fields.description: Contains provisional material from the Penn Treebank project. a subset of the Penn Treebank Corpus that has been tagged for part of speech. It contains (1) Wall Street Journal articles from the ACL Data Collection Initiative and (2) material donated by Mari Ostendorf of Boston University, consisting mainly of WBUR radio transcripts but also containing some ambiguous sentences.

fields.comment:
Annotated with the following types of linguistic information:

* Part-of-Speech tags following the "Stuttgart-Tübingen-Tagset" (STS 1999)
* Rhetorical relations of the 'Rhetorical Structure Theory' (MT 1988)
* Information structural notions such as Topic-Comment, Theme-Rheme and Cognitive Status
* Anaphoric relations
fields.name: Potsdam Commentary Corpus (Coreference)
fields.license_holder: use for scientific purposes only inside CoLi
fields.description: Consists of 173 texts (2195 sentences, 32962 tokens) of German newspaper commentaries taken from the online issue of the "Märkische Allgemeine Zeitung"

fields.name: German Parole Corpus
fields.description: A collection of modern Dutch texts amounting to c. 20 million tokens, for the greater part originating from newspaper or magazine articles. The texts are annotated for typographical and text-structural features. Each form has been automatically assigned a detailed part-of-speech code and a lemma.

fields.name: OpenThesaurus
fields.description: It contains the Deutscher Thesaurus (http://www.openthesaurus.de/)

fields.comment:
The NegraParser consists of the following two components:

(i) the LoPar parser of Helmut Schmid (IMS, University of Stuttgart), (ii) a treebank grammar read off from the NEGRA corpus (CoLi, Saarland University).
fields.name: NegraParser
fields.description: A stochastic parser for German providing for almost all sentences of German an analysis in the Penn format of the NEGRA corpus

fields.name: Muensteraner Corpus
fields.description: a part-of-speech tagged corpus of German from the University of Muenster from a variety of sources

fields.name: MRC Psycholinguistic Database
fields.description: A machine usable dictionary containing 150837 words with up to 26 linguistic and psycholinguistic attributes for each - psychological measures are recorded for only about 2500 words. The dictionary may be of use to researchers in psychology or linguistics to develop sets of experimental stimuli, or those in artificial intelligence and computer science who require psychological and linguistic descriptions of words.

fields.name: HCRC Map Task Corpus
fields.description: A set of 128 dialogues that has been recorded, transcribed, and annotated for a wide range of behaviours.

fields.comment:
File sizes: approx. 24 GB compressed (gzip'ed) text files
Number of tokens:    1,024,908,267,229
Number of sentences:    95,119,665,584
Number of unigrams:         13,588,391
Number of bigrams:         314,843,401
Number of trigrams:        977,069,902
Number of fourgrams:     1,313,818,354
Number of fivegrams:     1,176,470,663
fields.name: Web 1T 5-Gram Version1
fields.description: Contains English word n-grams and their observed frequency counts. The length of the n-grams ranges from unigrams (single words) to five-grams. Provided by Google Inc.

fields.name: GermaNet
fields.description: A lexical-semantic net that relates German nouns, verbs, and adjectives semantically by grouping lexical units that express the same concept into synsets and by defining semantic relations between these synsets.

fields.comment: Annotation : part-of-speech and syntactic tree annotation
fields.name: Genia Treebank
fields.license_holder: Free: For research and non-profit use

fields.comment: The corpus consists of three components: monolingual, parallel and annotated corpora. There are fourteen monolingual corpora, including both written and (for some languages) spoken data for fourteen South Asian languages: Assamese, Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Kashmiri, Malayalam, Marathi, Oriya, Punjabi, Sinhala, Tamil, Telegu and Urdu. The EMILLE monolingual corpora contain approximately 92,799,000 words (including 2,627,000 words of transcribed spoken data for Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Punjabi and Urdu). The parallel corpus consists of 200,000 words of text in English and its accompanying translations in Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, Gujarati and Urdu. The annotated component includes the Urdu monolingual and parallel corpora annotated for parts-of-speech, together with twenty written Hindi corpus files annotated to show the nature of demonstrative use.
fields.name: The EMILLE Corpus
fields.description: Enabling Minority Language Engineering (EMILLE) and Central Institute of Indian Languages (CIIL) corpus.

fields.comment: The corpus consists of three components: monolingual, parallel and annotated corpora. There are fourteen monolingual corpora, including both written and (for some languages) spoken data for fourteen South Asian languages: Assamese, Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Kashmiri, Malayalam, Marathi, Oriya, Punjabi, Sinhala, Tamil, Telegu and Urdu. The EMILLE monolingual corpora contain approximately 92,799,000 words (including 2,627,000 words of transcribed spoken data for Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Punjabi and Urdu). The parallel corpus consists of 200,000 words of text in English and its accompanying translations in Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, Gujarati and Urdu. The annotated component includes the Urdu monolingual and parallel corpora annotated for parts-of-speech, together with twenty written Hindi corpus files annotated to show the nature of demonstrative use.
fields.name: The EMILLE Corpus
fields.description: Enabling Minority Language Engineering (EMILLE) and Central Institute of Indian Languages (CIIL) corpus.

fields.comment: Complete listing of the languages and contents of the corpora can be found at http://www.elsnet.org/ecilisting.html
fields.name: European Corpus Initiative (ECI)
